pullRequest.body:
From FLT. Binary and finite products of modules with the module topology also have the module topology. 

---

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message

- ...

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ instProd`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

:v: kbuzzard can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12737281198/job/35498129353)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12737281198/job/35498129283)

Looks great, thanks! Just a bunch of nitpicks.

I might add that I think it's a bit crazy that we have to write proofs like the `instPi` one here manually. I wonder who could write a tactic for this?

bors d+

```suggestion
  -- But `i` can be written as (m, n)  (m, 0) + (0, n)
```

```suggestion
variable {M : Type*} [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] [TopologicalSpace M] [IsModuleTopology R M]
variable {N : Type*} [AddCommMonoid N] [Module R N] [TopologicalSpace N] [IsModuleTopology R N]
```

```suggestion
    infer_instance
```

```suggestion
variable {R : Type*} [TopologicalSpace R] [Semiring R]
```

Again this results from a clear-up of the proof and me not picking up the pieces. Thanks!

There is an argument for keeping named instances and that's that it's then possible to supply them later on with (`\tauR := moduleTopology`) or whatever); in the past I found this helpful but I'm getting better at doing these proofs now and they're looking more natural (for example the introduction of `P` defined to mean M x N but with a different topology so I need this crutch less.
Yeah, I noted the history and I agree there are definitely times when it's useful to have a name for typeclass parameters.

```suggestion
  have : ContinuousAdd M := toContinuousAdd R M
  have : ContinuousAdd N := toContinuousAdd R N
```
Do you understand the difference? There is no discernable difference in the infoview *shrug*. All I know is "I means inline now".

```suggestion
  let P : TopologicalSpace P := moduleTopology R P
  have : IsModuleTopology R P := rfl
  have : ContinuousAdd P := ModuleTopology.continuousAdd R P
```
As you're probably aware, I'm doing this on purpose, with the logic being "I heard that I means something else now but actually in Lean 4 we often use it in the same places as Lean 3 anyway"

I admit to having imperfect knowledge myself on this point but I don't think it's true that we often use it in the same places.

I believe the `I` in Lean 3 meant "instance" and the `I` in Lean 4 means "inline".

In Lean 3, there was this silliness that you had to opt terms you created in to typeclass search explicitly. So we had `letI` and `haveI` where the `I` was for "instance" (I believe). In Lean 4 the vanilla `let` and `have` are essentially equivalent to Lean 3's `letI` and `haveI`: terms are always opted in.

In Lean 4, I believe the point of `letI` and `haveI` is to avoid wrapping terms using [letFun](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Prelude.html#letFun). I don't understand this at all well but I think of `letI` and `haveI` as being almost macros so the use of this syntax has no (or almost no) effect on the terms created. OTOH `let` and `have` do use `letFun`. You can see some differences by inspecting the Lean state when the cursor is at the start of the proof in the following set of examples:
```lean
example (m : ) :
    let n := m + m
    Even n :=
  m, rfl

example (m : ) :
    letI n := m + m
    Even n :=
  m, rfl

example (m : ) :
    have h : 0 < m + 1 := m.zero_lt_succ
    ((m + 1, h : +) : ) = m + 1 :=
  rfl

example (m : ) :
    haveI h : 0 < m + 1 := m.zero_lt_succ
    ((m + 1, h : +) : ) = m + 1 :=
  rfl
```
So I use `letI` or `haveI` when I want the syntax to be friendly to a human but I want the term to be as though I'd written the whole term manually.

I think this helps clarify a bit:
```suggestion
  change @Continuous (M  N) P instTopologicalSpaceProd P i
```

```suggestion
instance instProd : IsModuleTopology R (M  N) := by
```

```suggestion
instance instPi : IsModuleTopology R ( i, A i) := by
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Topology/Algebra/Module/ModuleTopology): finite products of modules.
